title: Yamatohime-no-mikoto
text:
is a Japanese figure who is said to have established <a href="Ise%20Shrine">Ise Shrine</a>, where the Sun Goddess, <a href="Amaterasu%20Omikami">Amaterasu Omikami</a> is enshrined. Yamatohime-no-mikoto is recorded as being the daughter of <a href="Emperor%20Suinin">Emperor Suinin</a>, Japan's 11th Emperor.
Traditional historical view.
Legend says that about 2,000 years ago, <a href="Emperor%20Suinin">Emperor Suinin</a> ordered his daughter, Princess Yamatohime-no-mikoto, to set out and find a suitable permanent location from which to hold ceremonies for <a href="Amaterasu">Amaterasu Ōmikami</a>. Prior to this, <a href="Amaterasu">Amaterasu Ōmikami</a> had been worshiped within the Imperial Palace at <a href="Yamato%20Province">Yamato</a>, before a temporary location was created in the eastern <a href="Nara%20Prefecture">Nara Basin</a>. Yamatohime-no-mikoto is said to have set out from Mt. Miwa and wandered for 20 years through the regions of <a href="%C5%8Cmi%20Province">Ōmi</a> and <a href="Mino%20Province">Mino</a> in search of a suitable location.
When she arrived at <a href="Ise%20Province">Ise</a>, she is said to have heard the voice of <a href="Amaterasu">Amaterasu Ōmikami</a> saying that she wanted to live forever in the richly abundant area of Ise, near the mountains and the sea, and it was here that Yamatohime-no-mikoto established <a href="Ise%20Shrine">Naiku</a>, the Inner Shrine.
<a href="Jien">Jien</a> records that during the reign of <a href="Emperor%20Suinin">Emperor Suinin</a>, the first High Priestess ("<a href="sai%C5%8D">saiō</a>", also known as "saigū") was appointed to serve at Ise Shrine.
Later, during the reign of <a href="Emperor%20Keik%C5%8D">Emperor Keikō</a>, she gave her dress then holy sword "<a href="Kusanagi">Kusanagi-no-tsurugi</a>" to <a href="Yamato%20Takeru">Yamato Takeru</a>.
Alternate historical perspectives.
Some sources point out the parallels between Yamatohime-no-mikoto and <a href="Himiko%20%28queen%29">Queen Himiko</a>, a female ruler of Japan referred to in 3rd-century Chinese sources, namely the <a href="Records%20of%20Three%20Kingdoms">Records of Three Kingdoms</a> and the <a href="Wajinden">Wajinden</a>. Himiko was recorded as an unmarried queen and priestess, whose name means "sun child", or "sun daughter". Parallels can be drawn between Yamatohime-no-mikoto's role as both princess and priestess and the descriptions of Himiko, as well as the meaning of Himiko's name and that of the role of Yamatohime-no-mikoto as priestess and descendant of the sun goddess, or "daughter of the sun". Queen Himiko is recorded as having ruled the land of "Yamatai", whereas Yamatohime-no-mikoto left her home of <a href="Yamato%20Province">Yamato</a> to establish <a href="Ise%20Shrine">Ise Shrine</a>.
The nature of <a href="Himiko%20%28queen%29">Queen Himiko</a> has been a point of great debate since the late <a href="Edo%20period">Edo period</a>, with other theories linking her with <a href="Empress%20Jing%C5%AB">Empress Jingū</a> or even a real person upon whom the myth of the sun goddess <a href="Amaterasu">Amaterasu</a> was built. As the earliest extant Japanese sources of information about Yamatohime-no-mikoto date from the <a href="Kojiki">Kojiki</a> in the early 8th century, it remains difficult to see how the historical figure of Yamatohime-no-mikoto can be delineated in fuller depth or with a sense of better verified accuracy.
Ceremonies.
A <a href="Shinto">Shinto</a> ceremony is conducted on May 5 and November 5 each year at the sanctuary of Yamatohime-no-miya, near <a href="Ise%20Shrine">Ise Shrine</a>, to celebrate the contribution of Yamatohime-no-mikoto in the establishment of the shrine.
